utterances: We're definitely trustworthy and a lot of organizations are working with us.
Thank you, Jason.
Thank you.
I just want to remind our listeners that we're listening to TALK OF THE NATION on NPR News.
Wyclef, how do you, how do you keep a contributing organizations accountable for the results that you expect?
The way that we do it with Yele Haiti, we are hands on, like I'm always on the ground.
I have a team that I work with, a gentleman by the name of Hugh Locke, annual report every two months.
This is like, it's sort of like, you know, my record label would think I'm very crazy because they're like, yo, you're supposed to be making records, you know?
This is not, to me, as another celebrity with a charity.
I call it on-ground work.
So everything that's being done is being checked by me 100 percent.
Do you ever feel a conflict between your career, which supports your philanthropic work, and the work that you want to do in Haiti?
Do you ever feel torn?
Not at all.
Like I have the number one song in America right now with Shakira, Hips Don't Lie.
And I'm in Haiti like every two months.
So not at all, you know?
I'm a student of Bono.
Put it like that.
So you manage to keep going professionally and still kind of do good stuff.
But I have heard him say that he feels sometimes conflicted because his company does sometimes feel that he's spending too much time doing good works rather than making good records.
I mean, has no one ever said that to you, hey, you know what, we could use a little more in the studio?
They're always going to say that because, you know, you have the money aspect, you know what I'm saying, of people wanting to constantly make money.
But I think that it's all about a balance.
The more successful you become, the more you can help and make, you know.
So I think I pretty much keep it balanced, you know?
Let's go to Stacy in Naples, Florida.
Stacy, what's on your mind?
Hi.
How are you doing today?
Very well.
What's your question?
Good.
Yes, first I wanted to say Wyclef, man, you're absolutely amazing, an amazing artist and an amazing individual.
And my question to you is I work with a bunch of Haitians down here in the restaurant industry.
And the idea that I get from them is, you know, that they, when they go back to Haiti they're going to pick up arms and they're going to ostracize the country of, you know, the U.S.
government and everybody by force.
And that's how they're going to take it over.
My question to you is how do you get around that type of mentality, you know, which is the same question I ask them is how are they going to achieve peace by continued violence?
And how do you get around that?
Thank you, Stacy.
Well, first I want to say clearly there's nobody that's living in the states that is going to Haiti right now and pick up any arms to take on the U.S.
Like that's just a bunch of talk and a lot of bogus.
The people that are in Haiti, the gangs that actually live in Haiti, now they are saying that.
Then that's when you know it's for real.
I think that the people, a lot of people in the states, are speaking from frustration and the fact of what they're seeing in the news.
And I think unless you physically go on the ground, you don't have an idea of what's going on because everything is being blamed on the U.S.
in the sense of the U.S.
this, the U.S.
that, the U.S.
this, the U.S.
that.
I think the situation is clear right now in Haiti.
To move Haiti forward, we need the Haitian government to step up and take charge of what they're doing and basically fight corruption and go back and start raising money again.
What the donors promise, get that money going.
Try to raise the debt off of Haiti, the poorest country in the western Hemisphere.
You can't go any lower.
And then, at the end of every summer, he'd get on a train back to Grand Central Station.
And it would hit him.
So if I was the government, one of the first things I'd try to do is raise the debt from the country.
So I think the people up here are basically speaking from frustration.
So Yele Haiti is basically saying versus using all of that frustration energy because you're not going to go pick up arms.
Because if you were going to pick up arms, you would have did that already.
So we passed that point of the talk.
So the fact of the action is you physically have to get on a plane, go down there, see what the organizations are doing, and try to do something positive.
I think that's a fine way to end.
Grammy award-winning artist Wyclef Jean joined us from his recording studio in New York.
We leave you with Generation X from his 2004 record, Welcome to Haiti: Creole 101.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Michel Martin.
Thank you for joining us.
President Trump was on Capitol Hill today, leaning hard on House Republicans to vote for their party's health care bill to replace the Affordable Care Act.
The bill faces opposition from a group of hardline conservatives.
The House vote is scheduled in just two days.
NPR congressional correspondent Susan Davis reports from Capitol Hill on the president's push to close this deal.
President Trump wields a big shtick, and at today's meeting with House Republicans, he was not afraid to use it, says North Carolina lawmaker Richard Hudson.
I'm trying to think of a good analogy.
It was kind of like the ""Blue Collar Comedy Tour"" where you got the one guy who's performing and the other guys sitting that are kind of - he's feeding off of.
Trump performed for 45 minutes, and that other guy sitting there was House Speaker Paul Ryan.
The president and the speaker are working together to pass their bill to repeal and replace key pillars of the Affordable Care Act.
But they're not there yet, so Trump relied on a familiar routine.
He praised the lawmakers who are with him on the bill and called out the ones who are not.
Texas Republican Bill Flores says the president busted the chops of one Republican in particular.
Yeah, Mark Meadows he called out two or three times.
North Carolina Republican Mark Meadows is the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, a faction of about 30 hardline conservatives who are the leading opponents to the Republican's health care bill.
They say it doesn't go far enough to repeal the law and that there's not enough guarantees it will lower costs.
So Trump singled out Meadows by joking - at least Republicans say they think it was a joke - that he would campaign next year against lawmakers who vote against him.
Again, here's Flores.
(Laughter) The reaction when he said, Mark Meadows, I'm coming after you, was pretty loud cheers.
The Freedom Caucus built its name in the tea party era by opposing Republican Party leaders who had to work with President Obama.
Meadows also played a leading role to force out former Speaker John Boehner.
But their brand of conservative troublemaking is chafing their colleagues more now that a Republican is in the White House and the party has a chance to get their agenda signed into law.
New York lawmaker Chris Collins says the president made clear there will be consequences if Republicans defeat their own bill.
He said we would lose the House and the Senate if we don't get this passed.
With the vote scheduled for Thursday, Collins says this is a defining moment for these conservatives.
It's a binary choice for them.
They are the far-right that want a more dramatic cut, if you will, in Obamacare.
But if they vote no, then they get Obamacare for eternity.
It's a binary choice, and they have to struggle with that over the next three days.
Meadows says he didn't take Trump's singling out personally.
It also didn't move his vote.
He's still a no, and his vote count hasn't changed.
I've had no indication that any of my Freedom Caucus colleagues have switched their vote.
Meadows says he thinks there's still time to negotiate.
I certainly still think the president is the best guy to bring this home and close this deal out.
Hopefully we'll be able to do that.
But if everyone's entrenched at this particular point, it's going to be a very difficult 48 hours.
The vast majority of Republicans support this bill.
Chris Collins estimates they're about a dozen votes shy of what they need to pass it.
The president has been picking up votes one by one.
Texas Republican Blake Farenthold got on board just last week following a personal appeal from Trump at the White House.
His reasoning is simple.
I'd hate to go back home to Texas and say I had the opportunity to repeal Obamacare, and I didn't.
Conservatives like Meadows will have to decide this week whether it's better to go home and say they voted with President Trump or stood against him.
Susan Davis, NPR News, the Capitol.
President-elect Donald Trump continues to fill out his administration.
He made three key appointments on Friday.
Retired Army Lieutenant General Michael Flynn is Mr. Trump's pick for national security adviser.
Representative Mike Pompeo of Kansas has been tapped to be the new director of the CIA.
And Alabama Senator Jeff Sessions is Trump's pick for attorney general.
NPR's political editor Domenico Montanaro is joining us to dig into what these choices might tell us about the incoming administration.
Hi, Domenico.
Hello.
